name: Modified Muller-Lyer
description: The classic Muller-Lyer illusion is modified so that the blue line is objectively longer than the red line, while the arrowhead fins create the perceptual illusion that the red line is longer or that both are equal. Vision-language models, trained on the canonical illusion, report that the lines are equal or that the red line is longer, failing to perceive the actual size difference.
question: Which is longer, the blue line or the red line?
constraintExploited: Training data overfitting. Models learn the canonical illusion response from extensive training examples and reproduce it even when the stimulus has been modified so that the blue line is objectively longer.
sourcePapers: Ullman (2024) — illusion-illusion concept; adapted for AI detection

contributions.description: Initial submission with human validation, model testing, and agent deployment data
Extended Validation Study: 34 vision-language models tested via API (10 trials per trap per model, 2,040 total trials)

name: Modified Cafe Wall
description: The Cafe Wall illusion is modified with diagonal lines added between alternating rows of black and white tiles. Humans correctly perceive the diagonal slant, but vision-language models report the canonical Cafe Wall response (that the lines appear slanted when they are actually straight), failing to recognize that in this modified version the lines genuinely are slanted.
question: Are all the gray lines PERFECTLY STRAIGHT / HORIZONTAL or SLANTED / DIAGONAL?
constraintExploited: Training data overfitting. Models recognize the Cafe Wall pattern from training data and produce the canonical response without processing the actual geometric properties of the modified stimulus.
sourcePapers: Gregory and Heard (1979) — original Cafe Wall illusion

contributions.description: Initial submission with human validation, model testing, and agent deployment data
Extended Validation Study: 34 vision-language models tested via API (10 trials per trap per model, 2,040 total trials)

name: Modified Ebbinghaus
description: The Ebbinghaus (Titchener circles) illusion is modified so that the red circle is objectively larger than the blue circle, while the surrounding context circles create the standard size-contrast illusion. Models trained on the canonical illusion report that the circles are the same size or that the blue circle is larger.
question: Which is bigger, the blue circle or the red circle?
constraintExploited: Training data overfitting. The Ebbinghaus illusion is well-documented in training data. Models reproduce the learned canonical response rather than performing direct visual measurement on the modified stimulus.

contributions.description: Initial submission with human validation, model testing, and agent deployment data
Extended Validation Study: 34 vision-language models tested via API (10 trials per trap per model, 2,040 total trials)

name: Moving Robot
description: A robot moves progressively across four steps with consistent speed and trajectory. The task requires extrapolating the robot's position at Step 4 based on the pattern shown in Steps 1-3. Vision-language models fail because they process each frame independently rather than integrating motion across the temporal sequence.
question: Across each step, the robot moves with the same speed and trajectory. Where is it most likely that the robot will be located on Step 4?
correctAnswer: Mostly around the center of the square
responseOptions: Mostly around the center of the square
constraintExploited: Spatiotemporal reasoning. Models process each frame independently rather than integrating motion across a temporal sequence. They cannot extrapolate trajectories from sequential visual information.
sourcePapers: Zhou et al. (2025) — VLM4D benchmark documenting spatiotemporal reasoning failures

contributions.description: Initial submission with human validation, model testing, and agent deployment data
Extended Validation Study: 34 vision-language models tested via API (10 trials per trap per model, 2,040 total trials)

name: Colliding Oranges
description: A set of shapes in a 2D display where the participant predicts which objects would collide if the largest circle moved in a straight line toward the smallest circle. This requires mental simulation of physical movement and spatial reasoning about object positions and sizes.
question: The largest circle will move straight to the left towards the smallest circle. What are the objects in the way, if any?
constraintExploited: Spatial reasoning with mental simulation. Models struggle to simulate physical movement through 2D space and reason about which objects lie in the path of motion, especially when object sizes and positions require integrated spatial judgment.
sourcePapers: Qi et al. (2025); Stogiannidis et al. (2025) — spatial reasoning and mental simulation benchmarks

contributions.description: Initial submission with human validation, model testing, and agent deployment data
Extended Validation Study: 34 vision-language models tested via API (10 trials per trap per model, 2,040 total trials)

name: Surrounded Planets
description: Six colored planets are each surrounded by several geometric shapes. Five planets have 5 shapes surrounding them; one planet has only 4. The task requires counting shapes around each planet and identifying the one with fewer shapes. Models struggle to correctly bind shapes to specific planets when visual elements overlap and occlude each other.
question: Each planet is surrounded by several shapes. Five planets have 5 shapes surrounding them. One planet has 4 shapes. What color is the planet that has only 4 shapes?
constraintExploited: Cross-modal binding with occluded stimuli. Models fail to correctly bind visual elements (shapes) to specific referents (planets) when elements overlap and partially occlude each other.
sourcePapers: Campbell et al. (2024); Kamath et al. (2023) — cross-modal binding benchmarks

contributions.description: Initial submission with human validation, model testing, and agent deployment data
Extended Validation Study: 34 vision-language models tested via API (10 trials per trap per model, 2,040 total trials)

name: Shape Overload
description: An image contains circles, rectangles, triangles, and hexagons in various colors. The participant must first identify which shape type appears in the most different colors, then count how many of that shape are present. This requires compositional reasoning: integrating shape identity, color variation, and counting in sequence.
question: One of these shape types appears in more different colors than the other three. First, identify which shape appears with most colors. Then, count how many of those shapes are in the image.
constraintExploited: Compositional counting. Models struggle with multi-step visual reasoning that requires identifying a category, applying a criterion, and then counting instances.
sourcePapers: Guo et al. (2025) — compositional counting benchmarks

contributions.description: Initial submission with human validation and model testing data
